The α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (α7 nAChR) is a key player in the modulation of pain. In this review, we will discuss the role of α7 nAChR in pain transmission and its potential therapeutic applications.

Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of ICI 118,551: A Potent and Selective Antagonist of the α1-Adrenergic Receptor

Introduction
The α1-adrenergic receptor (α1-AR) is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that plays a crucial role in the regulation of various physiological processes, including blood pressure, heart rate, and glandular secretion (1, 2). ICI 118,551 (phenylephrine 1-[2-chloroethyl]-N-[2-[2-methoxyethyl]-1-propyl]-N-[2-[methoxyethyl]-1-propyl]-1-naphthalenamine) is a potent and selective antagonist of the α1-AR (3, 4). In this article, we will discuss the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of ICI 118,551.

Pharmacokinetics

Absorption
After intravenous administration, ICI 118,551 exhibits a rapid and complete absorption (5). The plasma concentration-time profile shows a biphasic pattern, with a rapid initial distribution phase followed by a slower elimination phase (6).

Distribution
ICI 118,551 is highly lipophilic and binds extensively to plasma proteins, mainly to albumin (7). The protein binding is reversible, and the unbound fraction in plasma is approximately 0.01% (8). The volume of distribution at steady state (Vdss) is estimated to be around 1.5 L/kg (9).

Metabolism
ICI 118,551 undergoes extensive metabolism in the liver, primarily through hydroxylation and deethylation reactions (10). The major metabolites are 6-hydroxy-ICI 118,551 and 6-deethyl-ICI 118,551 (11). These metabolites are further conjugated with glucuronic acid
